unit_learning_outcomes.description: Describe theoretical frameworks for the assessment of/and therapeutic intervention for musculoskeletal tissues.
Describe introductory concepts in biomechanical analysis and mechanical properties of musculoskeletal tissue.
Understand the principles of a scientist-clinican and the application of evidence-based practice.
Describe the position of chiropractic within public health and it's role in primary health care.
Demonstrate entry-level skills in patient assessment within a framework of ethical patient interaction.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading to support the delivery of material in lectures. Weeks 1-12
3 hours of class preparation per week to support the learning of of the practical components covered in the tutorials. Weeks 2-13

assessments.description: Formal end of session written exam to assess all theoretical components of the unit.

A practical test conducted after the mid-session break during scheduled classes. This test is the equivalent of 1 station in the final OSCE. The test assesses acquisition of practical skills acquired in this unit.

A practical test conducted before the mid-session break during scheduled classes. This test is the equivalent of 1 station in the final OSCE. The test assesses acquisition of practical skills acquired in this unit.This test is formative and is for feedback only.
A report discussing the role chiropractic care plays in the delivery of primary health care. This assessment task requires students to develop and demonstrate library and research skills.

assessments.assessment_title: End of session - Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE)
assessments.description: Objective Structural Clinical Exam (OSCE): A practical exam, organised into stations conducted during the end of session practical examination period (Week 13). The OSCE will assess all practical components of this unit.
Online quiz conducted before the mid-session break. Assesses theoretical components of the unit thus far.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 1, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Special circumstances, North Ryde
data.description: This unit offers an introduction to Chiropractic practice including patient assessment and intervention using spinal palpation, range of motion and fundamentals of psychomotor skill acquisition. The clinical application of anatomical knowledge is explored. Research methodology and critical thinking skills essential for the health clinician are introduced as part of the research skills development program. Fundamental biomechanics related to function and manual therapy intervention are introduced. The role of Chiropractic in the delivery of primary health care, both now and throughout history are explored.
data.title: Chiropractic Sciences 1
